Metallic nickel (5 wt%) supported on alumina catalysts were synthesized using a mechanochemical one-pot synthesis method. To investigate the effect on catalytic performance and stability, the catalysts were prepared by varying the water-to-aluminum isopropoxide molar ratio during synthesis. An increase in the amount of water led to enlarged pore sizes and volumes. Long-term dry reforming of methane (DRM) tests revealed that while the initial catalytic activity was similar by pore size and volume, however, coke deposition, which is expected to be the main for catalyst deactivation, was significantly influenced. Catalysts with smaller pores exhibited greater coke formation after the reaction, which is likely due to mass transfer limitations. Coke formation was significantly suppressed in the catalyst with larger pores, attributed to improved mass transfer. These results demonstrate that even in high-temperature gas-phase reactions, pore structure can play a critical role in catalyst deactivation, thereby highlighting the potential of mechanochemical one-pot synthesis as a strategy for advanced catalyst design. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mechanochemistry One-pot synthesis Dry reforming Nickel Alumina Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methane is one of the most abundant hydrocarbon compounds, constituting the major component of natural gas [1] and possessing a global warming potential 28–36 times greater than that of CO2 [2]. The dry reforming of methane (DRM) (Eq. 1) is a critical reaction for carbon mitigation, as it converts two major greenhouse gases—methane and carbon dioxide—into syngas (a mixture of CO and H2), a valuable intermediate for producing fuels and chemicals [3]. However, several side reactions can occur in the reactor, such as methane decomposition (Eq. 2), reverse Boudouard reaction (Eq. 3), and reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS) (Eq. 4). These side reactions can negatively impact the process by causing coke formation and lowering the H2/CO ratio [4,5]. (1) CH4 + CO2 → 2CO + 2H2 (ΔH° = 247.3kJ/mol−1) (2) CH4 → C + 2H2 (ΔH° = 74.9kJ/mol−1) (3) 2CO → C + CO2 (ΔH° = -172 kJ/mol−1) (4) CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O (ΔH° = 41kJ/mol−1) Ni-based catalysts supported on alumina have long been regarded as among the most promising candidates for DRM [6] due to their low cost and reasonable catalytic performance relative to noble metals [7]. However, the high reaction temperatures required for DRM, typically 700–800 °C, owing to its highly endothermic nature [8], render Ni catalysts particularly susceptible to deactivation through sintering and coke formation [9]. To address these challenges, various strategies have been investigated, among which enhancing the metal–support interaction is considered one of the most effective approaches to improve catalyst performance [10,11]. One-pot synthesis offers a promising route to strengthen the interaction between the active metal and support by incorporating metal precursors directly into the support synthesis step [12–14]. This approach enables in situ integration of active species and support, thus mitigating issues observed in conventional impregnation methods. Among the different one-pot techniques, liquid-phase strategies such as evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) [15,16] and sol–gel synthesis [17,18] have been extensively explored for molecular-level catalyst design. However, these methods often suffer from drawbacks such as significant wastewater generation and high production costs. Mechanochemical synthesis, which predominantly relies on solid-state reactions, presents an attractive alternative [19–21]. It eliminates the need for solvents [22,23], thereby minimizing wastewater production and allowing greater flexibility in precursor selection [24]. Previous studies have demonstrated the feasibility of mechanochemical methods for preparing a range of porous materials, including zeolites [23,25], mesoporous carbons [26], and metal oxides [27–30]. Notably, Zhang et al. [31] reported the successful synthesis of mesoporous alumina with a narrow pore size distribution via a mechanochemical route using aluminum isopropoxide and the triblock copolymer surfactant Pluronic P-123. This surfactant, widely used as a template in mesoporous materials such as SBA-15, enables pore structure control through variations in concentration, pH, additives, and temperature, which influence micelle formation [32–34]. While the influence of pore structure on catalyst performance and stability is well established in liquid-phase reactions [35–40] due to mass transfer limitations, this relationship has been less emphasized in gas-phase systems, where diffusion constraints are typically minimal. However, recent studies have underscored the significance of pore structure in gas-phase reactions that are prone to severe coking, such as catalytic methane decomposition [41–43]. Nevertheless, when using catalysts synthesized via conventional impregnation methods, it is difficult to decouple the effect of pore size from other variables, such as surface area, which can strongly affect metal dispersion and particle size. In this study, a series of 5 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with systematically varied pore structures were synthesized via a mechanochemical one-pot method. The objective was to investigate how pore size influences the catalytic activity and long-term stability of Ni-based catalysts under the harsh conditions of DRM. The catalysts were evaluated over a 100-hour time-on-stream test, and their performance and extent of coke formation were comparatively analyzed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemical reagents for the precursor and catalyst synthesis were used without any purification or modification. Aluminum isopropoxide (AIP, Al[OCH(CH3)2]3, ≥ 98 %, Sigma-Aldrich) and Pluronic P-123 (PEG-PPG-PEG, Average Mw ∼5800, Sigma-Aldrich) were used to synthesize alumina. Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate [Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, 97 %, Sigma-Aldrich] was used to Ni incorporation into the alumina. 2.2 Catalyst preparation method Ni/Al2O3 were synthesized mechanochemical nonhydrolytic sol-gel process reported by Zhang et al. [31]. 10 g of aluminum isopropoxide and 4 g of Pluronic P-123 templates were added in a 125 mL zirconia grinding jar with 10 mm zirconia ball (ball-to-powder weight ratio = 10). In case of one-pot synthesized Ni/Al2O3, nickel nitrate precursor corresponding to 5 wt% of the total catalyst, based on metallic Ni, is measured and added. To control the pore size, distilled water is added in amounts corresponding to 0, 1, or 3 times the molar quantity of aluminum isopropoxide. The sealed jar was then placed in a BM6Pro planetary ball-milling machine (Beijing Grinder Instrument Co. Ltd., China) and milled at 400 RPM for 1 h. The resulting mixture was calcined without a drying step at 800 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min to obtain the final product. The mechanochemically synthesized 5 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were designated as M-NiAl-x, where x represents the molar ratio of H2O to aluminum isopropoxide. 2.3 Catalytic reaction DRM reaction performance of catalysts was evaluated using 1/4 in. quartz-tube fixed bed reactor under ambient pressure using 0.15 g of catalyst. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 800 ℃ in 100 % H2 flow for 2.5 hr. Then, the DRM reaction was conducted at 700 ℃ with 100-hours with a CH4:CO2:N2 feed ratio of 1.0:1.1:1 to compensate the fluctuation of gas flow and a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 20,000 mL/gcat·hr. Outlet mixture gas was analyzed using thermal conductivity detector in Chromass 6500GC gas chromatography (Young-In, Korea). Detailed analysis of pore size distribution and structure was conducted using a AutoPore IV 9500 Mercury Intrusion Porosimeter (Micromeritics, USA). The phase and grain size information were obtained X-ray Diffraction (XRD) with DteX250(H) (Rigaku, Japan) operated at 40 kV and 50 mA, using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Hydrogen Temperature-programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were conducted using BELCAT II catalyst analyzer (MicrotracBEL, Japan). The sample was pretreated in pure Ar (50 mL/min) at 200 °C for 2 h and then cooled to 50 °C. Subsequently, it was reduced under a 5 % H₂/Ar gas mixture (50 mL/min) by heating from 50 ℃ to 1000 ℃ at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted for defining surface composition and chemical states of support using NEXSA (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The morphology and crystal size of the catalyst was evaluated by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) with TECNAI F20 UT analytical electron microscope (Philips, Netherland) in Gwangju Center of Korea Basic Science Institute. The statistical Ni particle size was estimated by averaging at least 100 Ni particles for reduced catalyst and 50 Ni particles for spent catalyst using ImageJ software. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out to determine the amount of coke using TGA2 (Mettler Toledo, Switzerland) under 60 mL/min of air flow by heating from 30 °C to 900 ℃ at a ramp rate of 10 ℃/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption–desorption analysis was conducted to evaluate the textural properties of the mechanochemically synthesized Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 1(a) and (b) show the N₂ adsorption–desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distributions, respectively, while the corresponding textural parameters are summarized in Table 1. Although all three catalysts exhibited similar BET surface areas of approximately 200 m2/g, notable differences were observed in their pore structures. The isotherms revealed that the M-NiAl-0 and M-NiAl-1 catalysts exhibited H4-type hysteresis loops, typically associated with micro–mesoporous materials, whereas the M-NiAl-3 catalyst displayed an H3-type hysteresis loop, indicative of a macroporous network [44]. With increasing H₂O/AIP molar ratio, both the average pore size and pore volume increased gradually. According to the BJH pore size distributions, the M-NiAl-0 and M-NiAl-1 samples exhibited unimodal profiles with peaks centered at 4.6 nm and 6.2 nm, respectively. In contrast, the M-NiAl-3 catalyst showed a broad mesopore distribution in the range of 10–30 nm, accompanied by macropores exceeding 50 nm. These findings suggest that at lower H₂O/AIP ratios, the catalysts retain a unimodal mesoporous structure, while higher ratios promote the development of hierarchical pore structures comprising both meso- and macropores. To gain further insight into the pore structure, mercury intrusion porosimetry was performed, and the resulting log differential intrusion curves are presented in Fig. 1(c). This analysis revealed differences in pore structure more distinctly. The M-NiAl-3 catalyst exhibited a bimodal distribution with pronounced peaks at 11 nm and 40 nm, with negligible contribution from mesopores smaller than 5 nm. Similarly, the M-NiAl-0 catalyst showed a bimodal distribution with peaks at 3.6 nm and 6 nm, with most of the pore volume concentrated around 4 nm. In contrast, the M-NiAl-1 catalyst displayed a unimodal distribution centered at approximately 6 nm, consistent with the BJH analysis results. These mercury porosimetry results further confirmed that increasing the H₂O/AIP molar ratio leads to larger pore sizes and greater pore volumes. The alteration of the pore structure by the H2O/AIP ratio is attributed to the hydrolysis of AIP. During the mechanochemical reaction, AIP decomposes to form aluminum hydroxide, and its crystalline phase can be influenced by the amount of water present. To support this hypothesis, Fig. S1 shows the XRD patterns of AIP powders dried after ball-milling at H2O/AIP ratio of 0 and 3. The results reveal a slight phase transformation from gibbsite (#33–0018) to nordstrandite (#24–0006) as the H2O/AIP ratio increased from 0 to 3. This confirms that the change in the pore structure is affected by the hydrolysis of AIP, which depends on the water content. This hypothesis is further supported by the pore structure analysis results for catalysts with an H2O/AIP ratio of 3 or higher. Fig. S2 and Table S1 show the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis results for M-NiAl-3, M-NiAl-4, and M-NiAl-5 catalysts, confirming that once the H2O/AIP ratio exceeds the stoichiometric ratio of 3, it does not significantly impact the pore structure. Fig. 2 illustrates the XRD spectra of M-NiAl catalysts reduced at 800 ℃. The XRD pattern of catalysts revealed characteristic peaks corresponding to γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS#50–0741) and metallic Ni (JCPDS#04–0850). While the metallic Ni peaks displayed slight variations in crystallinity depending on the catalyst, the γ-Al2O3 nearly unchanged across all samples. To assume the approximate size of the Ni particles, the Scherrer equation was applied based on the main peaks of metallic Ni located at 2θ = 44.5°, and the calculated values are presented in Table 2. Consistent with the trend observed in catalyst surface areas from N₂ physisorption analysis, the Ni particle sizes of the M-NiAl-0 and M-NiAl-1 catalysts were similar, approximately 17–18 nm. In contrast, the M-NiAl-3 catalyst exhibited a smaller Ni particle size of 11.4 nm. These results suggest that even when catalysts are synthesized via the one-pot method and have comparable surface areas, variations in pore structure can influence the Ni particle size, and thus its dispersion. This suggests that, in addition to potential changes in mass transfer or reaction mechanisms, pore structure may also indirectly affect the stability of the catalyst. Hydrogen Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted to obtain information about interaction between active metal species and support material (described in Fig. 3). For all three catalysts, the main reduction peak of Ni appeared above 800 ℃, assigned NiAl2O4 species [45]. Although minor reduction peak associated with free NiO, which is typically observed below 400 ℃ [45], was detected at 339 ℃, the relatively small peak area suggests that its contribution is negligible. In comparison of the main reduction peaks, the M-NiAl-3 catalysts—with the largest pore size and volume—exhibited the peak at the lowest temperature. In contrast, the M-NiAl-0 and M-NiAl-1 catalysts, which have similar pore size and volumes, showed nearly overlapping peak positions. These results suggest that as the H2O/AIP ratio increases from 0 to 3, the incorporated water may weaken the interaction between Ni and Al2O3 during the synthesis process. The elemental composition and chemical properties of catalyst surface was investigated by XPS. The elemental composition of each reduced catalyst as determined by XPS analysis is summarized in Table 3. All values are given in weight percentage by calculation. Although the nominal composition of the synthesized catalysts was 5 wt% Ni, the Ni content measured on the surface was remarkably low, below 2 wt% for all samples. Notably, the surface Ni content followed a similar trend to the pore size, indicating that larger pore sizes may lead to more exposure of Ni on the external surface. For the O 1 s spectra shown in Fig. 4(a), the peaks of the reduced M-NiAl catalysts were deconvoluted into two components: an Al–O bond peak at 530.5 eV [46] and an Al–OH bond peak at 531.6 eV [47]. Fig. 4(b) displays the Al 2p spectra, which were similarly deconvoluted into two peaks corresponding to the Al–O bond at 73.6 eV and the Al–OH bond at 74.4 eV, respectively [46]. Surface hydroxyl groups (Al–OH species) on alumina are known to be associated with acid–base surface properties [48–51]. The proportion of the Al–OH peak area relative to the total O 1 s and Al 2p peak areas is summarized in Table 4. All three catalysts exhibited similar values, ranging from 32 % to 34 %, indicating no significant differences in the surface characteristics of the alumina supports. On the other hand, the Ni 2p spectra in Fig. 4(c) reveals that the positions of the Ni species peaks are different among catalysts. For the M-NiAl-3 catalyst, the metallic Ni and Ni2+ peak is located at a binding energy approximately 0.4 eV lower than those of the other two catalysts. This trend is in good agreement with the reducibility of Ni confirmed by the TPR results. The morphology and statistical Ni particle size were obtained by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). Based on statistical measurements from TEM images (in Fig. 5), all three catalysts were found to have Ni particle sizes in the range of approximately 9–10 nm. These results indicate that the one-pot synthesis method enables the formation of Ni particles with relatively uniform sizes, regardless of variations in pore structure. Typically, when the Ni particle size exceeds the pore size, metal particles are more likely to be located on the external surface of the support rather than inside the pores. However, in this case, a substantial number of Ni particles were observed within the alumina grains, suggesting that the one-pot synthesis method promotes deeper integration of the active metal into the support. 3.2 Reaction test The CH4 conversion, CO2 conversion, and H2/CO ratio during the DRM reaction are presented in Fig. 6. In the early stage of the reaction, all three catalysts exhibited a CH4 conversion of approximately 80 %, indicating that the catalytic activity was largely governed by the amount of active metal (Ni) loaded on the catalyst, while the influence of pore structure and interaction between metal and support was negligible. After 100 h of DRM reaction, it was observed that catalysts except M-NiAl-0 maintained stable performance without severe deactivation. The M-NiAl-0 catalyst, which had the smallest pore size and volume among the three, experienced a rapid pressure increase due to coke formation during the reaction, leading to reaction termination within 6 h. This result highlights that even when surface area and Ni particle size are comparable, the pore structure plays a crucial role in determining catalyst stability. A similar trend was observed in the comparison between M-NiAl-1 and M-NiAl-3, the M-NiAl-3 catalyst exhibited almost no decrease in CH4 conversion even after 100 h of reaction, whereas the M-NiAl-1 catalyst showed a slight decline of approximately 2 % in CH4 conversion. The H2/CO ratio was approximately 0.9 for all three catalysts. This is likely attributed to the concurrent occurrence of the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction as a side reaction. The RWGS reaction was probably facilitated by a slight decrease in the reactor temperature, caused by the highly endothermic nature of DRM, as well as by the reaction being conducted under a slightly elevated partial pressure of CO2. Furthermore, the H2/CO ratio followed the same trend as the CH4 and CO2 conversion, suggesting that the reaction mechanism did not vary among the catalysts. To evaluate the extent of coke formation on the catalyst after the reaction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted, and the results are presented in Fig. 7. In general, weight loss observed below 200 ℃ in TGA analysis is primarily attributed to adsorbed water or gases [52], while coke is known to decompose at temperatures above 400 ℃ [53]. Therefore, only the weight loss occurring above 400 ℃ was considered as the amount of coke formed. The M-NiAl-3 catalyst showed only a 2.2 % weight loss due to coke decomposition even after 100 h of reaction, indicating its superior resistance to coke formation. In contrast, the M-NiAl-0 catalyst, which experienced premature reaction termination after only 6 h due to pressure increase caused by severe coking, showed a significant weight loss of 31.0 %, reflecting a high tendency for carbon deposition. Among the catalysts that maintained activity throughout the 100-hour test, the M-NiAl-1 catalyst showed a 12.8 % weight loss—approximately 6 times that of M-NiAl-3—further highlighting the beneficial effect of increased pore size and volume in suppressing coke formation. To confirm the changes in catalyst characteristics due to sintering or coke formation after the reaction, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis and statistical analysis of Ni particle size through TEM analysis of the spent catalysts were conducted. Fig. 8 showed the BJH pore size distribution for the fresh and spent catalysts. After the reaction, a decrease in the pore volume of the mesoporous region was observed in all catalysts, which is attributed to the coke formation during the reaction. However, for M-NiAl-0 (Fig. 8a) and M-NiAl-1 catalysts (Fig. 8b), the peak position of the pore distribution showed little change, remaining at approximately 4 nm and 7 nm, respectively. In contrast, for the M-NiAl-3 catalyst (Fig. 8c), a shift in the peak of the pore size distribution from 16 nm to 9 nm was observed. This phenomenon is expected to be due to the blockage of pore entrances by coke formation, leading to a reduction in the number of accessible pores in M-NiAl-0 and M-NiAl-1 catalyst. Conversely, in the case of M-NiAl-3 catalyst, even with coke formation, the coke is deposited on the walls inside larger pores, which decreases the pore size and volumes but does not significantly reduce the number of accessible pores. Regarding sintering, TEM image analysis (in Fig. 9) revealed that the statistical Ni particle size was observed to become larger only in the M-NiAl-3 catalyst. Although slight sintering of Ni particle occurred in the M-NiAl-3 catalyst and given larger Ni particle sizes are known to favor coke formation [54], coke formation suppressed. This means that pore structure effect is more influential than particle sintering in these catalysts. Despite the catalysts exhibiting similar characteristics in terms of Ni particle size, interaction between metal and support, surface area, and the chemical state of the alumina support except pore size and volumes, the significant differences observed in coke formation are most likely attributed to variations in mass transfer caused by differences in pore structure. 4 Conclusion In this study, pore-size controlled Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized via mechanochemical one-pot synthesis method. Characterization results confirmed that the three catalysts exhibited nearly identical properties in terms of Ni particle size (approximately 10 nm) and interaction between metal and support, and surface area, aside from differences in pore structure. To compare their reactivity and stability, dry reforming of methane reaction was conducted for 100 h. While the initial conversions were nearly the same, significant differences in stability were observed depending on the pore size and volume of the catalysts. Catalysts with smaller pores showed a greater tendency for coke formation, likely due to mass transfer limitations. These findings highlight that pore-induced mass transfer effects play a critical role even in high-temperature gas-phase reactions, and that control over pore structure via precise catalyst design presents a promising strategy for improving catalytic stability. coredata.dc:description: Metallic nickel (5 wt%) supported on alumina catalysts were synthesized using a mechanochemical one-pot synthesis method. To investigate the effect on catalytic performance and stability, the catalysts were prepared by varying the water-to-aluminum isopropoxide molar ratio during synthesis. An increase in the amount of water led to enlarged pore sizes and volumes. Long-term dry reforming of methane (DRM) tests revealed that while the initial catalytic activity was similar by pore size and volume, however, coke deposition, which is expected to be the main for catalyst deactivation, was significantly influenced. Catalysts with smaller pores exhibited greater coke formation after the reaction, which is likely due to mass transfer limitations. Coke formation was significantly suppressed in the catalyst with larger pores, attributed to improved mass transfer. These results demonstrate that even in high-temperature gas-phase reactions, pore structure can play a critical role in catalyst deactivation, thereby highlighting the potential of mechanochemical one-pot synthesis as a strategy for advanced catalyst design.
